text.value:
Here are the steps to add a project to Git version control:
1. Navigate to the project directory in your terminal/command prompt.
2. Initialize a new Git repository by running:
```bash git init ```
3. Add all the files in the project to the staging area by running:
```bash git add . ```
4. Commit the files with an initial commit message:
```bash git commit -m "Initial commit" ```
5. Add a remote origin URL pointing to a new repository on GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket etc:
```bash git remote add origin <remote_url> ```
6. Push the commits to the remote repository:
```bash git push -u origin master ```
Now your project is version controlled with Git and hosted on the remote repository. You can make changes locally, commit them and push to update the remote.
Let me know if you need any clarification or have additional questions!

Here are a few suggestions to try to locate and install the pgadmin4-web package:
- Make sure your system is up-to-date by running `sudo apt update`. This will refresh your package index.
- Search for the package to see if it's available in your repositories: `apt search pgadmin4-web`
- The pgadmin4-web package may be in a different repository than the default ones. Try enabling the PostgreSQL repository for your Linux distribution and updating again. For example, on Ubuntu:
``` sudo sh -c 'echo "deb http://apt.postgresql.org/pub/repos/apt $(lsb_release -cs)-pgdg main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/pgdg.list' sudo wget --quiet -O - https://www.postgresql.org/media/keys/ACCC4CF8.asc | sudo apt-key add - sudo apt update ```
- If it's still not found, the package may have been renamed or removed from the repositories. Search for similar package names like `pgadmin4` or `pgadmin`.
- As a last resort, you can try to install pgAdmin4 directly from source following the instructions on their website: https://www.pgadmin.org/download/pgadmin-4-apt/
- Check for any errors during `apt update` or `apt install` to troubleshoot further.
